article.title: Investigation of Defect Modes of Chiral Photonic Crystals

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 1 depicts the effect of defect position within a CLC system on various parameters. According to the figure, when are Q factors and relative PDOS (pm/piso) at their extremum?
choices: When the defect is at the boundaries of the CLC layers
When the defect is slightly shifted towards one of the CLC layers
When the defect is in the midplane of the system
When the defect position aligns with the peak reflectance for left-handed circularly polarized light

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 2 shows 3D dependences of transmittance (T) and reflectance (R) on wavelength (λ) and the refractive index of the surrounding medium (n0). What is the effect of increasing Fresnel reflections (increasing difference between \'a\' and unity) on the defect mode for incident light?
choices: Increases the dip of the defect mode for both right- and left-handed circularly polarized light.
Reduces the dip of the defect mode for right-handed circularly polarized light and increases the peak for left-handed circularly polarized light.
Has no significant impact on the defect mode.
Completely suppresses the defect mode for left-handed circularly polarized light.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 3 illustrates the impact of the difference between the average CLC refractive index and the surrounding medium refractive index (Δn) on the defect mode. What happens to the defect mode with left-handed circular polarization when Δn = 0?
choices: It shifts to a shorter wavelength.
It becomes independent of Fresnel reflections.

multiple_choice_question.text: Figure 4 presents the dependence of the natural logarithm of the Q factor (lnQ) on the CLC layer thickness (d/σ). According to the figure, how does lnQ change with increasing CLC thickness?
